I.  INTRODUCTION 
     
1. In a rapidly changing global and regional environment, timely and accurate economic 
information is important for sound policy decisions. The rapid integration of regional economies 
has also increased the tempo of economic cycles, creating the need for frequent evaluation and 
assessment of existing economic policies.  If it is to be able to recommend relevant and 
appropriate  policy  measures  to  its  developing  member  countries  (DMCs),  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) must keep abreast of current development issues. ADB’s capacity for 
internal economic analysis and research therefore needs to be strengthened.   
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2. ADB  is  committed  to  pursuing  sustainable  economic  growth,  inclusive  social 
development, and governance for effective policies and institutions in the region. To support 
these efforts, ADB must have at its disposal a comprehensive assessment of current economic 
trends, policy issues, and medium-term development prospects in the Asian and Pacific region. 
ADB publishes the annual Asian Development Outlook1 (ADO) and ADO Update, which provide 
detailed  macroeconomic  profiles  and  medium-term  growth  prospects  of  the  developing 
economies in the region. They also cover the global economic environment and include a brief 
discussion on a relevant macro policy issue. An in-depth analysis of a special thematic issue is 
presented in Part III of ADO. To enhance and reinforce the knowledge base for this undertaking, 
technical  assistance2  (TA)  to  strengthen  the  economic  analysis  underpinning  the 
macroeconomic  assessments  in  ADO  and  ADO  Update,  as  well  as  to  support  production 
quality, is proposed.  
 
3.   The TA will continue to support ADB’s goal of providing high-quality and comprehensive 
economic assessments of trends, issues, and development prospects in the region. The TA will 
contribute to ADB's visibility among senior policymakers in the DMCs, international research 
institutions, multilateral organizations, and the academic community. ADO and ADO Update 
launches are also major media outreach events for ADB. 
 
4.  To strengthen the forecasts and analyses in ADO, developing econometric models was 
emphasized.  The  previous  TA3  supported  an  economic  modeling  conference  to  initiate 
collaboration and partnership among model builders and model users in the Asia-Pacific region. 
The TA also supported the development of macroeconometric models for the People’s Republic 
of China and the Philippines. These models have subsequently generated baseline forecasts for 
these two DMCs that were used in the ADO 2004 Update.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
5.  The TA aims to improve the content and quality of ADO and ADO Update by further 
developing economic forecasting and policy analysis models in support of ADB’s short- and 
medium-term country economic analysis and by ensuring high-quality economic editing of the 
country economic reports. The models being developed will be used to generate the short- and

medium-term economic forecasts in the country chapters of ADO 2005 and ADO 2005 Update, 
as well as to strengthen the economic underpinnings of country programs and strategies for the 
DMCs to be covered. The models will also be used to improve the analytical content of ADO 
and  ADO  Update  through  quantitative  analysis  of  economic  policy.  Economic  editing  will 
improve the quality and internal consistency of the analysis in the country economic chapters.  
The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  The following major activities are the milestones for the TA: 
 
(i)  Together with ADB country economists in regional departments (RDs) and resident 
missions  (RMs)  and  economists  and  econometricians  in  institutions  in  selected 
DMCs, develop economic forecasting and policy analysis models based on available 
indicators.  
 
(ii)  Organize a training workshop for the country writers of ADO 2005 and ADO 2005 
Update on macroeconomics and forecasting techniques.  
 
(iii)  Organize  a  second  economic  modeling  conference  to  discuss  progress  in  the 
modeling exercises and exchange experience across the different countries.  
 
(iv)  Hire the services of well-qualified economics editors to review the economic analysis 
in the country chapters for ADO 2005 and ADO 2005 Update.   
 
7  The country participants in the ADO training workshop will be nominated by the RDs and 
RMs. Draft country chapters on each of ADB’s borrowing member countries will be prepared by 
country economists of the RDs and RMs. The Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division 
(ERMF) will prepare draft country chapters on each of ADB’s non-borrowing DMCs, administer 
the ADO training workshop, coordinate the preparation of ADO 2005 and ADO 2005 Update, 
and  participate  in  the  dissemination  of  both  publications.  The  participants  in  the  second 
economic modeling conference will be selected in consultation with the RDs and RMs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
8  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $250,000 equivalent4 (Appendix 2). The entire TA 
will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
9.  ERMF will implement the TA in close collaboration with the RDs (East and Central Asia, 
Southeast Asia, South Asia, Mekong, and Pacific) and RMs. Developing the models will be a 
collaborative exercise involving ERMF economists, country economists of the RDs and RMs, 
and national experts, so as to collectively build up capacity and ensure sustainability of the 
investments in the economic forecasting and policy analysis modeling work. The DMCs targeted 
for  the  modeling  exercise  under  this  TA  will  be  ADB’s  larger  borrowers  where  quarterly 
economic data are available, namely, Bangladesh, India, Thailand, Pakistan, and Viet Nam. 
Other DMCs will be invited to the ADO technical conferences to share their experience of

quarterly modeling and to share the use of their models with ERMF and the ADB country 
economists. The TA is expected to begin in December 2004 and to be completed by December 
2005. 
 
10.  The ADO Training Workshop for the country chapter writers on macroeoconomics and 
forecasting techniques is tentatively scheduled for December 2004 at ADB headquarters. The 
economic modeling conference is tentatively scheduled for mid-2005 at ADB headquarters. The 
number of participants will be limited in order to maximize interactions. This second economic 
modeling conference will review new and existing models as well as modeling activities in 
selected DMCs. Major international institutions such as the International Monetary Fund, the 
World Bank and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development will be invited to 
share their modeling experiences in the selected DMCs.   
 
11.  The TA secretariat will consist of a TA supervising unit (TASU) officer, an economics 
officer, and an administrative assistant. The main responsibilities of the secretariat will be as 
follows.  First,  in  close  collaboration  with  the  RDs  and  the  RMs,  it  will  develop  baseline 
assumptions on external conditions, and development and policy issues to guide the country 
economists who will prepare individual country reports on recent economic developments and 
medium-term prospects. Second, the secretariat will plan and manage the ADO economic 
modeling conference. Third, it will initiate networking with selected institutions in the region who 
are actively involved in model building. Fourth, publication activities for ADO 2005 will be 
undertaken and research results will be disseminated globally in collaboration with the Office of 
External Relations (OER), RMs and representative offices. Fifth, publication and dissemination 
activities for ADO 2005 Update will be undertaken six months after publication of ADO 2005. 
 
12.  For ADO 2005, five domestic macroeoconometric modeling consultants (30 person-days 
each); one international economic editor (70 person-days); and one international copy editor 
cum desktop publishing specialist (60 person-days) will be engaged. For ADO 2005 Update, 
one international economics editor (20 person-days) and one international copy editor cum 
desktop publishing specialist (20 person-days) will be engaged. Appendix 3 gives the outline 
terms of reference for the consultants. The editors will review the draft manuscript before final 
publication. ADB will select and engage the consultants in accordance with the Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for selecting and engaging domestic consultants. 
 
13.  ADB staff will disseminate the major results of ADO 2005 and ADO 2005 Update to the 
media, DMC policymakers, and the academic community. The dissemination activities will be 
coordinated by OER in cooperation with ERMF. The RMs launch the publications in selected 
DMCs. Both publications will be featured in the ADB Web site, and CD-ROM and printed copies 
will be distributed worldwide. ERMF will circulate internally a report on the outcome of the 
modeling exercise with proposals on how to build on this TA for future issues of ADO and in 
possible applications of the macroeconometric models in country work.

4  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis for 
Asian Development Outlook 2005, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Country Economic Modeling Consultants 
1.  The  consultants  should  have  excellent  working  experience  in  macroeconometric 
modeling and good knowledge of the developing member country (DMC) economy. Under the 
direct supervision of the technical assistance supervising unit (TASU) officer, the consultants 
will perform the following:   
 
(i)  Develop  a  small-scale  macroeconometric  model  of  the  selected  DMC  using 
quarterly data, and test the model for robustness in terms of economic structure 
as  well  as parameter  estimates. The  model should  generate  sensible  policy 
simulation results. 
(ii)  Prepare a summary report of the model specifications, residual analysis, test 
results, and performance evaluation. 
(iii)  Design and develop a database system to support the model, document the 
sources and definitions of variables contained in the database, and develop a 
data-updating routine. 
(iv)  Work with the TASU secretariat on the model tests. 
(v)  Work with the TASU secretariat on an outline for future expansion of the model to 
be used by Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
 
B.  Economics Editor 
  
2.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of the Macroeconomics and 
Finance Research Division (ERMF) and in consultation with other ADB staff members in the 
Economics and Research Department (ERD) involved in preparing and reviewing the country 
chapters in Asian Development Outlook (ADO) 2005 and ADO 2005 Update, the economics editor 
will edit the manuscripts for consistency and economic content. The editor will help prepare the 
highlights (English version) of the publication. The editor will ensure that all the data in the 
publication is based on the most recent information available as of the cut-off date.  
 
3.  In particular, the economics editor will 
 
(i)  edit ADO for consistency with economic theory as well as empirical evidence; 
(ii)  edit ADO for internal consistency; 
(iii)   edit ADO for balanced coverage and degree of detail and precision; 
(iv)   check the report for structure, content, and format to ensure that it conforms to  
  the prescribed requirements for ADO; 
(v)  review the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in the  
  text; 
(vi)  confer with ERMF staff regarding gaps in the text, important questions, and  
  revisions needed; 
(vii)  help prepare the publication highlights; 
(viii)  help prepare the key messages and review press releases for ADO; and 
(ix)  perform all other functions and responsibilities as may be assigned by the 
assistant chief economist of ERMF.
